headline: DTE Energy Co., 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2011
componenttextpreview: Good day and welcome to the  DTE Energy Year-end 2010 Earnings Release Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] At this time, I would like to turn the conference over to Mr. Dave Meador. Please go ahead, sir.
componenttext: Good day and welcome to the  DTE Energy Year-end 2010 Earnings Release Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] At this time, I would like to turn the conference over to Mr. Dave Meador. Please go ahead, sir.

headline: DTE Energy Co., 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thank you, and good morning to everybody and welcome to our year-end conference call. Before we have started at like to refer you to our Safe Harbor statement which is on Page 2 including the reference to forward-looking statements.With me this morning
componenttext:
Thank you, and good morning to everybody and welcome to our year-end conference call. Before we have started at like to refer you to our Safe Harbor statement which is on Page 2 including the reference to forward-looking statements.
With me this morning are Gerry Anderson, Pete Oleksiak and Nick Khouri and Mark Rolling and we also have other members of the management team that we can call in the Q&A session if needed. With that brief introduction at me turn it over to Gerry.

headline: DTE Energy Co., 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Dave. Good morning, everyone and thanks for being with us this morning. I'm going to cover two topics today:First, I want to quickly review 2010 and some of our accomplishments last year. And then, I'm going to move on to a look-forward to 2011
componenttext:
Thanks, Dave. Good morning, everyone and thanks for being with us this morning. I'm going to cover two topics today:
First, I want to quickly review 2010 and some of our accomplishments last year. And then, I'm going to move on to a look-forward to 2011 and a few years beyond 2011.
In that second topic, I think is especially important because you'll see later, 2011 for us is a bridge year, between what's been a period of very healthy earnings growth over the last three years and a period in 2012 and beyond, that we're confident will resume that pattern of earnings growth. So more on that in a few minutes.
So moving on to Slide 5, we look back on 2010 as a really successful year for DTE Energy. On the earnings front, our EPS grew 9% year-over-year last year. And in fact, grew at a 9% compound rate for the last three years. In addition last year, we had essentially 11% ROE at both of our utilities so we earned our authorized and also had solid earnings in our Non-Utility businesses where a a strong year in our Power & Industrial business covered for a weaker year in our Energy Trading business.
On a cash flow front, our metrics remain strong. We were upgraded by S&P late in the year, which was something we've been working hard at for several years, so that was gratifying. We also increased our dividends, 6%.
We also kept a intense focus as we have over the past five years, on continuous Improvement, and we continue to reap dividends from this effort within the company. So as I'll talk in a few minutes our absolute O&M is down over the past five years and we continue to work hard on our costs. But increasingly, we're turning this continuous Improvement toward the customer front. You can see that our complaints for example, at the public service commission are down 50% over the past five years.
And as I'll talk further in a little bit, we undertook a big step last year, in sense calling back every customer we have an interaction with using the log defects, where we got things we need to fix and then we're going after that with our CI.
We also undertook a lot of work on our growth agenda this past year. We announced our first major Renewable Energy project, a major win project that I'll talk about a little later. We began construction on our second scrubber at Monroe and as you'll see later, we've got a substantial investment program over the next three years in emission controls, and we launched several new projects in our Power & Industrial business, particularly the Reduced Emissions Fuel business line, which is a significant new business line, that I'll lay out some facts on in a few minutes, as well as our Waste with Renewables business line.
And moving on to Slide 6, talking a little bit more about Continuous Improvement.
I mentioned that this continues to be an important focus for us at the company. You can see from the graphic on the cost front, that our CI initiatives have more than offset structural cost pressures over the last five years so absolute utility O&M is down over $100 million, despite upward pressure and tensioned healthcare, environmental additions at our power plants, general inflation and so forth. And our work here is to keep driving each area of the company to top-quartile operating performance and as we achieve that, push beyond that.
In addition to the cost savings, we're, as I said a minute ago, really focusing the CI effort more and more on the customer front. Outage frequency, improved fieldwork, options for  low-income customers and so forth. The reason for all of this is our belief that the companies that do the best during significant investment cycles and we are in one of those, the companies that do best are those that aggressively manage affordability and maintain constructive regulatory relationships. And our belief is, the best way to accomplish those two things is Continuous Improvement focused on cost and customer-service. To put differently, to get constructive regulation, you need to deserve it, you need to earn it. And that's especially true when heavy investment is putting pressure on rates. And our job is to use this Continuous Improvement process to offset those rate pressures, manage affordability and improve service quality, and if we do that well, we believe the odds of constructive regulation and fair treatment are much higher.
Now, speaking of constructive regulation, on Slide 7, one of the things that's certainly changed for the better than Michigan in recent years is a regulatory structure and a regulatory processes. You can see on Slide 6 some of the highlights and important regulatory developments for our utilities this past year. Starting with the final order we received at Detroit Edison earlier in the year, which we characterized and continue to understand as we went through the years as a constructive order. We held off, as you can see, further right on this slide, we held off on filing a new rate case at Detroit Edison as long as we could, but did eventually file in October, and I think if you'd take a look at that filing, you'll also see that we took some very creative steps within it to manage affordability and the amount that we need to increase rates for customers.
That case, we would expect to self-implement under in April and the case will go final in October. On the MichCon front, we received the final order as he can see in the middle of the slide in June, we did file a rate case pretty quickly on the heels of that. But as the year went on and we continue to work on our costs, and watched the behavior of things within the company, we eventually determined that we could forgo the case and we did that with drawing the case in December, concluding that, that was the right thing to do from a customer-affordability prospective.
Moving on to Slide 8. Another thing that's changed for the better in Michigan over the past year, is the economy. You can see on the left-hand side of the slide, what's happening on the industrial front. The strong performance of the auto companies has been getting a lot of attention nationally, but the industrial turnaround that we're seeing has been pretty broad. As you can see, we were up 21% this past year, which led to an overall growth and territory sales of 3%. That turnaround is translating into the employment of folks here in Michigan as well. You can see that the unemployment rate which peaked at about 14.5% was down to 11.7% by the end of the year. So that's a positive development.
Another indicator of health in the economy is our arrears, and you can see that we took a big step down in arrears this past year. Our uncollectible expense that's associated with that was down sharply last year as well.
So I think the range of indicators suggest that we have worked our way through the events of the recession and we've got a nice recovery in the underlying economy here in Michigan.
On to Slide 9. I'm not going to turn from a look back on 2010, to a look forward to this year and the next few years. I mentioned earlier that the past three years have been a period of very healthy earnings growth for DTE. Earnings per share have grown 9% annually, between 2007 and 2010.
Our EPS guidance for this year, 2011 is roughly flat to 2010 levels, it's actually down a bit at the midpoint of our guidance. As you can see from Slide 10.
And at DTE, we are talking very explicitly with our employees about 2011 being a bridge year. A bridge between that period of healthy earnings growth from 2007 to 2010, and a period in 2012 and beyond that I'm confident is going to resume that pattern of healthy earnings growth, 5% to 6% a year it's what we've been saying for a long time as our target and that's what we foresee.
So one question might be why are we so confident that 2011 is this bridge and we're going to see that resumption of earnings growth next year and beyond. That's one of the things we want to help you understand this morning, and I think to do that, you need to both look back and look forward. You need to look back to understand the dynamics that are shaping our earnings this year in 2011, and look forward at the investments that we are making this year and that we have underway that will play out over the next two years and beyond that will shape earnings in the future.
So what I want to do is take that look back and look forward and I'll do that with our utilities and then turn to our non-utilities businesses. 
And then on Slide 11, I laid this out for Detroit Edison and MichCon, from 2007 to 2010 those businesses, we saw combined utility earnings growth of 9%. We also used continues improvement to bring the ROE's in those two businesses to their allowed levels but during that period, of course the economic crisis hit and we pulled back investment pretty sharply like a lot of people did because of the capital market uncertainty and to manage customer affordability.
And the result of that pullback is putting out this year. So if you look in the middle of the slide you'll see that our combined utility earnings growth is projected at about 3% in 2011. That's less certainly than we've seen in recent years and less than our long-term growth of 5% to 6% but it's really is a result of a lag impact from our reduction in investment in the heart of the crisis.
But as you'll see in a few minutes, this is a your 2011 where we resume strong investments in utilities, especially in renewable power and emission controls within Detroit Edison. And the result of that, on the right-hand, portion of the Slide 11, is that we do expect to see a resumption of 5% to 6% annual growth in our utilities in 2012 and beyond. And in addition, in that period, the renewable investments that were beginning to ramp back up and the environment investments will be actually heavier next year and the few years beyond that.
So this is what I just described is I think even clearer on Slide 12, where you can see our capital spending pattern, we had been planning a period of quite heavy investment in 2009 and 2010 when the crisis hit. You can see how we pulled back, especially sharply in 2009. And we only really start up capital a bit this past year, and this is what temporarily slowed the growth in rate base and what's playing through with the lag here in 2011.
If you look at this year, and the next two years though, you can see in the late blue bars in the green bars, that our emission control investments and renewable investments are going to stop up materially. Total capital expenditures will be $1 billion to $1.2 billion in 2011 and as you can see $2.4 billion to $2.8 billion over two-year period, 2012 and 2013. You also see a kind of rotten green box in 2011 with a gray arrow, I'll tell you a little bit about more that in a minute but there's a Renewable Energy project, a wind farm that we're pursuing with a partner. And the arrangement we have in the partner is there going to construct  the project and we're going to buy in as that construction plays out. We're going to finish up the construction this year. So we may buy in, a roughly $200 million portion of the project, late this year or at the very beginning of next year or. So that's $200 million could swing in either late 2011 or early 2012.
You can also see that in the light blue here, the emission control expenditures, ramp back up substantially as we prepare for requirements that are targeted for 2015.
So this step up in capital spending at Detroit Edison is further laid out on Slide 13. The biggest piece of that investment is in our base infrastructure where we see $7 million to $800 million,, $2.1 billion to $2.3 billion in a period to go but the real growth in our earnings power and rate base is coming from the right two columns. Our environmental compliance expenditures, $800 million to $900 million over the three-year period is related targeted to finishing to scrubbers and coming close to finishing one additional SER at our Monroe Power Plant.
In addition to that, we see $500 million to $600 million of Renewable Energy expenditures. The state for us has a requirement of 300 megawatts in place by 2013, so within the next three years. And we have the right under law, to own half of that so our projected expenditures to make that play out are $500 million to $600 million over the next three years. And the details of that renewable expenditure are laid out on Slide 14. And the first thing I'd focus you on is the Red Star there in the middle of the state. That's a project that I mentioned a minute ago that we're pursuing jointly with Indian
[ph]. 
It's a 200-megawatt wind farm. We are going to own 90 megawatts of that installation, about $200 million capital investment. And as I said a minute ago, the way this is playing out is that d we will buy-in for our piece as the project  close to ready to go commercial. You can see the impact of that at the bottom left of the slide, we have a substantial step up in our earnings from Renewable Energy, and energy optimization as we go from 2011 to 2012. And this is certainly one of the things that is driving a return to earnings growth at a higher level at Detroit Edison in 2012.
And if you look down the road, as I mentioned, we need to add to that project between 2012 in 2013. We expect to do that using the 78,000 acres of fuse means that we have under contract in Huron County, that's designated, there by the purple star. We are working on those and we expect those investments on the heels of this Invenergy investment to take earnings in this business lines to about $15 million by 2015, as you can see we'll have a significant portion of that in place by the middle of this period 2013.
That's' gone, moving on to Slide 15. We will also be investing substantial capital over the next three years, about $500 million to $600 million over that or about $175 million to $200 million a year. The MichCon's investment agenda is laid out on Slide 15. The most significant element of MichCon's investment are in the gas distribution network, and in particular, we have been working with the Michigan Public Service Commission on a multiyear main renewal and meter move-out improvement that steps out the capital that we will be committing to our distribution infrastructure.
In addition to that, we continue to find opportunities within our Utility Storage & Transportation asset-base to expand storage, generally what we find customers want us to expand our storage, we contact with those customers and often have pipeline investments that are needed to take that storage to market. That's been added area of investment in recent years and we think that will continue here over the next two years.
So in summary, for Detroit Edison and MichCon, we're coming off a two-year period in 2009 and 2010 where we reduced capital expenditures in the wake of the economic crisis, but our capital expenditures, renewables, emission controls, gasman renewables, and mood meter move out, are going to drive our rate base investment up pretty sharply over the next three years. Our average capital spending and our utilities over the next three years will be about a third higher then it was last year For example. And as this investment will that enable us to bid bridge from about 3% utility earnings rate of 5% to 6% next year and beyond.
Slide 16 takes a similar multi-year look back and look-forward for our Non-Utility businesses. From 2007 to 2010, our two principal Non-Utility businesses, Gas Storage and Pipelines and Power & Industrial both grew at a healthy rate, 20% compound annual growth for those two businesses over the three-year period.
Energy Trading averaged earnings of about $45 million. Although as you know, our last year that three-year period was a low year for us. The other significant event during those three years was a $1.5 billion monetization of our unconventional gas assets.
2011 for these businesses is a bridge year, too. Our P&I earnings are going to be lower than last year. P&I earnings were very high last year but we have some items as I'll describe in a minute. They aren't going to occur this year, but we are scaling up at Power & Industrial through investments in reduced emissions, renewables and we do continue to identify investment opportunities in our Gas Storage and Pipelines business, and we are making progress on those. 
In addition, we are working to rebound from reduced earnings levels in Energy Trading in the last few months as Dave Meador will describe have been promising on that front. And we do continue to work this year to position for the monetization of our unconventional gas assets.
So if I look forward to the next few years in the Non-Utility front, we see reduced emission fuels and renewable investments providing a very substantial growth within our Power & Industrial segment, we have investments that will produce earnings growth at Gas Storage and Pipelines and we think our Energy Trading will return to more normal historical levels. 
That will combine with a move to monetize unconventional gas assets, which will be used to fund growth and this set of dynamics will also contrary to the 5% to 6% growth we're describing in 2012 and beyond.
One of the key adamant that I've just described is the projected growth in our Power and Industrial business and is laid out on Slide 17. First, on the left-hand side of the slide, and actually we first laid this out with his past fall while at EEI, we saw a big step up this past year in earnings. Earnings between nine and 10 more than doubled but some of the items were nonrecurring, so For example,, we saw high coal prices and we have capacity open and that played to our favor, that's not going to occur next year period. We also have the steel tax credit industry, or actually did think that was going to recur or right to the very end of the tax bill this past year but it did get pulled to our surprise and the steel industry's surprise, so those dynamics are producing a step down and earnings of P&I this year.
But as you can see from the light blue and dark blue bars, here we have two segments in this business that we expect to grow materially over the next number of years. One of those in the light blue is the Reduced Emission Fuels segment. And as just as a result reminder, these are products where we have technology that can be used to cold plans to reduce mercury and observations and also benefit from a federal tax credit. We are making progress on developing these other projects. We completed the sale of an interest in one of these products and we had it up and running. That was completed in January, and we are in negotiations with a number of other potential counterparties who run power plants a lot like Detroit Edison and does and face the same Emission Control requirements that we do, and our goal this year is to get several facilities with those counter-parties cited and up and running so that we see the substantial step up in earnings from this segment that's indicated here in 2012. And a little bit longer-term, we do expect to have our facilities pretty much fully in-place[ph] by 2013, and that $40 million to $50 million largely in place by then.
On the Renewable Energy front, this past year, we made significant progress in this arena. We purchased a majority ownership of a 44-megawatt plant in California late in the year. We'll bring that online late this year. We also came to agreement on a 45-megawatt facility in California that we now have in the conversion process that we'll bring online early in 2013. Those two projects brought the total that we have in this segment of Waste Wood projects from small coal plants brought the total to five, and so we're going to see growth just from that base of five projects that we brought online or are bringing online, but we'd expect to continue to find and invest in additional projects here.
So [indiscernible] of all this that we expect the P&I segment to be one of our significant growth areas over the next three years, and contribute to the 5% to 6% that I described earlier. 
We also see opportunities in our Gas Storage and Pipeline business and that's laid out of Slide 18. Our strongest opportunities in this segment center on the Millennium Pipeline, which is shown there in dark blue, runs from upstate New York into the New York City area. And also as you can see, it runs through the Marcellus shale and most of our development opportunities for that pipe center on gas that's emerging from the Marcellus shale. And those opportunities come from in the form of mainline pipe expansions, as well as a laterals off of the pipeline, and eventually connectors between Millennium and other pipelines.
And we are making progress on this front as well, in fact, I think the discussions went from pretty introductory and new early last year to discussions that are getting quite promising and serious early this year. 
So [indiscernible]  Here is that over the next three years, we see this is the period that this Gas Storage and Pipeline business, which grew a lot in over the last five years will make the investments that will fuel its next significant step up in growth.
So in summary, for the company then, on Slide 19, our investments in the top left are going to be up materially over the next three years. On average, if you compare the last three years to the next three years, we are up about on the order 25% and that's tied to our investments in Detroit Edison renewable assets, our environmental investments, principally at the mineral power plant, and the Non-Utility investments in P&I and our gas and storage and pipeline that I just mentioned. And I would also say, that the utility investments that we're taking with strong eye on managing customer affordability as I mentioned at the very outset of this discussion.
But if you look at what that implies in terms of investment base and earnings for the next few years, our earnings this year, we've given guidance of $340 million to $370 million, within that we do see utility earnings growth of about 3%. But as you can see, we expect earnings at both the ability and our Non-Utility businesses to pick up in 2012 and 2013 and we're projecting the 5% to 6% longer-term growth there that we've talked about for sometime.
So with that, I'm going to turn things over to Dave Meador to take a little bit closer look at 2010, and our 2011 guidance. Dave, over to you.

headline: DTE Energy Co., 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Gerry and good morning, again to everybody. I'm going to start on Slide 21.For the year, our operating earnings are $607 million or $3.60 per share, which is at the midpoint of our guidance. And as a reminder, there's a reconciliation to our GAA
componenttext:
Thanks, Gerry and good morning, again to everybody. I'm going to start on Slide 21.
For the year, our operating earnings are $607 million or $3.60 per share, which is at the midpoint of our guidance. And as a reminder, there's a reconciliation to our GAAP reported earnings in the appendix, as well as there are other information on the appendix that I hope you will find helpful. The $3.60 per share is a nickel higher than the midpoint of our original guidance for the year at $3.55, and is $0.30 or 9% higher than our 2009 operating earnings. Detroit Edison contributed $2.60  per share and MichCon came in at $0.63. Both utilities did a great job and as Gerry mentioned there in the authorized returns in 2010. We are seeing improvements in the local economy, that we also aligned on the low chart and
with Detroit Edison' temperature normal electric load of 3%, and that was driven predominantly by the industrial sector, which was up 21%. 
The Non-Utility business combined to earn $0.78, with Power & Industrial products earning $85 million, or $0.50 per share with a very strong year-over-year performance. And as we indicated this won't be repeated in 2011. Gas Storage and Pipelines came in at 4% higher than 2009 at $51 million or $0.30 per share, and Energy Trading had net earnings of $0.04 and Unconventional Gas Production had $0.06 a loss.
Finally, Corporate & Other had a loss of $0.41 for the year. And overall 2010 was a very good year for as. The performance came in very strong with the bulk of the earnings coming from the two utilities which have returned to their full earnings power.
And as Gerry outlined, the Power & Industrial business had a very strong performance almost offsetting the shortfall at Energy Trading.
Now shifting to 2011 and our outlook for the year on Slide 22. We outline our 2011 earnings guidance for each of the segments. As I've just said, both of our utilities earned their authorized return on equities in 2010 and we expect to do the same this year in 2011. We have a rate case at Detroit Edison, which will be finalized by the fourth quarter, and we're doing everything we believe is necessary to ensure constructive order from the commission and I'll talk a little bit more about that case in a moment. 
In MichCon, we plan to return to a normal weather year, after a warmer than normal in 2010 and lower midstream revenues. Also, at the utilities, we will leverage our continuous improvement capabilities to partially offset O&M expense.
Earnings at Gas Storage and Pipelines will be up another 4% in 2011, as we continue to identify long-term expansion and development opportunities around the Millennium Pipeline.
In 2010, we impaired some non-strategic leases at our Non-conventional Construction business and that won't reoccur in 2011. Also, we are seeing more oil and natural gas liquids production in our Barnett shale properties which is driving higher earnings in 2011. We've included in the appendix some key operating metrics for the business as well as a scheduled which summarizes the valuation for the Barnett assets and a couple of points I want to point out here. Given the nature of our properties, we get a 50% to 60% lift in revenues from natural gas liquids, and we are also pursuing some wells that add oil to our performance.
Currently the value derived from one MCF of gas is about $6.40, which is a nice premium over dry gas prices.  Once a year, we update the reserve analysis for this business and we provide the valuation range which is on Slide 35, and even if you use the conservative low-end of the valuation, and our current reserves are worth at least $400 million, or $2.35 per share, and then the midpoint of that range obviously is much higher. Our plan is to still develop the properties for monetization with a focus on natural gas, liquids and oil, and at the same time, we're going to eliminate the drag down on earnings this year.
The Power & Industrial team is coming off a very strong year that we just talked about for 2010, which included some opportunities which won't reoccur going forward such as the steel industry fills[ph],  tax credit and premium earnings on Coke sales. As Gerry explained, the story with the P&I group is the potential earnings opportunity from the REF business line an the coal-to-waste width conversions.  We'll start to see some earnings from this businesses in 2011, but we'll really start to scale up those lines in 2012 and forward. 
2010 as you know was a challenging year for our Energy Trading business, after a strong first quarter, we saw the markets flat now in he second half of the year with lower volatility and lower commodity prices.
In the third quarter, the business struggled to find market opportunities to generate sufficient gross margins,  however, that begin to change noticeably in November and December. In January, and so far in February this year, we have found trading opportunities returning in areas like power trading and full requirement contracts with gross margins in those months, similar to prior years. In fact, in January, we earned about 20% of the economic gross margin that we have assumed in our full-year guidance.
While we don't see this business going back to historical levels of $40 million to $50 million of operating income this year, we do expect it to make a significant step in that direction and we set the midpoint of guidance at $25 million.
Finally, we are expecting Corporate & Other to have improved results in 2011 primarily due to lower interest rate expense. So in total, we project DTE Energy to have operating earnings of $576 million to $631 million or $3.40 to $3.70 per share.
On Slide 23, we have an overview of the Detroit Edison rate case. We filed the case at the end of October, with a total revenue requirement of $443 million. And as an example of how we are focusing on customer affordability in this rate filing, we proposed some potential alternatives, which could reduce the net rate request by nearly $200 million for a net rate request of $253 million. We're looking forward to working collaboratively with the commission on this rate case over the next coming months.  Testimonies is due at the beginning of April and we plan to self-implement our rate increase in April. 
We will receive the final order in this case no later than the end of October. 
Now turning to cash flows on Slide 24. In 2009, we had one of the strongest cash years in our history with cash from operations of $1.8 billion, and I'm pleased to report, that we achieved same level  of cash from operations in 2010. And we're looking at 2011 with expected even stronger cash results of $1.9 million in cash from operations.
If you looked at total cash after capital and dividend and asset sales for 2009 and 2010 combined, we generated $850 million in total cash flow over two years. As Gerry explained earlier, after a slowing CapEx during the recession we plan to ramp it back up in 2011. We said in past we expect to issue between $100 million to $200 million of new equity to fund our growth over the next several years.  However, as a result of strong cash flows in 2010 and anticipated benefits from bonus depreciation of around $100 million to $200 million between 2011 and 2012, we're not expecting to issue any new equity this year and we are working on reducing our equity needs to 2012.
In Slide 25, we provided a breakdown for our 2011 capital plan. If you look at our capital for the utilities, going back it was $960 million in 2009. It was $1 billion in 2010. And we'll be spending about $1.2 billion in 2011, which is nearly a 25% increase over 2009 levels. At Detroit Edison, as we outlined, we are in the process of scrubbing the two remaining units in Monroe and we expect to have a sharp step-up in our environmental capital for the year. And as we outlined in 2010, we began construction on 200-megawatt wind farm. We'll take ownership of 90 megawatts of that generation in late this year late, or early next year which will be about a $200 million investment for Detroit Edison. 
And in MichCon, we're playing on increasing our capital spending by over 20% in 2011, and this is driven primarily by our pipeline integrity and meter relocation work.  And then at the non-utility business, we're targeting capital investments of $200 million to $300 million.
Slide 26 summarizes our balance sheet metrics. We ended the year with our target leverage range and we expect to be within that range for 2011. As a result of one-time deferred tax items in 2010, we realized FFO-to-debt of 28%,  which is well above our targeted range. We expect that to return to targeted levels in 2011 and as a result of our strong balance sheet and cash flows we secured a credit upgrade from S&P at DTE Energy and at both the utilities in December of last year also of which revised Detroit Edison's outlook to positive last month and in both cases, the agency's noted the economic conditions that are improving in Michigan and a very positive regulatory environment that we have here.
let  me wrap up on Slide 27. As we've outlined for you, we have a plan that we're confident in that will provide 5% to 6% long-term operating growth, and at the same time, provides an attractive dividend which combined, provide a very attractive total shareholder return, and at the same time, doing all of that by maintaining a very strong balance sheet. As Gerry very laid out, our utility growth plan is primarily driven by mandated investments and all of this is set in a very constructive regulatory structure that we understand that we have to continue to earn everyday by doing things by driving cost savings, which will enable our utilities to earn their authorized returns. And continuing to focus on operational excellence including customer satisfaction, which we believe over time will, create a distinctive capability in this company compared to others in the industry with a real focus on affordability.
At to compliment the utilities, we have meaningful low-risk growth opportunities in our non-utility businesses that will provide diversity both in earnings and geographic reach.
With that, that wraps up our presentation and we'd be happy to take your questions.

headline: DTE Energy Co., 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2011
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] And our first question comes from Paul Ridzon with KeyBanc.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] And our first question comes from Paul Ridzon with KeyBanc.

headline: DTE Energy Co., 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2011
componenttextpreview: Could you just give a little more timing on the monetization of the unconventional and what that could imply as far as your ongoing equity needs?
componenttext: Could you just give a little more timing on the monetization of the unconventional and what that could imply as far as your ongoing equity needs?

headline: DTE Energy Co., 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2011
componenttextpreview: I'll start and then Gerry will join me. If you look back at our analyst meeting a year and a half ago, we said to fund our growth we would need a certain amount of capital and/or, excuse me, to support our capital growth we need to issue equity and/or ass
componenttext: I'll start and then Gerry will join me. If you look back at our analyst meeting a year and a half ago, we said to fund our growth we would need a certain amount of capital and/or, excuse me, to support our capital growth we need to issue equity and/or asset sales. And subsequently, we translated that into about $100 million to $200 million of equity per year and through our strong cash flows as we indicated there'd be no equity this year we're going to drive that down next year. One of the levers that we have here going forward is monetization of the remaining properties in the Barnett shale. We are currently as we indicated, are proving up the properties with the real focus on what I would describe as the wet nature of the gas which is giving us an uplift in our prices and we are currently evaluating when we would start monetizing either small parcels of property or larger parcels over the next several years.

headline: DTE Energy Co., 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2011
componenttextpreview: So the $100 mil to $200 million is kind of what you need but that could be tapped down a little bit selling by some Barnett?
componenttext: So the $100 mil to $200 million is kind of what you need but that could be tapped down a little bit selling by some Barnett?

headline: DTE Energy Co., 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes.
componenttext: Yes.

headline: DTE Energy Co., 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2011
componenttextpreview: And then, of the $100 million to $200 million of bonus depreciation benefit, how much of that is at the regulated utility, and what's the impact on rate base and is that baked into your 5% to 6% growth?
componenttext: And then, of the $100 million to $200 million of bonus depreciation benefit, how much of that is at the regulated utility, and what's the impact on rate base and is that baked into your 5% to 6% growth?

headline: DTE Energy Co., 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2011
componenttextpreview: First of all, it is baked into our 5% to 6% growth. And I don't have the breakout on utility, non-utility. We have been taking some of the 50% depreciation across the company, and some of this does apply to our non-utility businesses. So for example, you'
componenttext: First of all, it is baked into our 5% to 6% growth. And I don't have the breakout on utility, non-utility. We have been taking some of the 50% depreciation across the company, and some of this does apply to our non-utility businesses. So for example, you've heard us talk about our Mount Pozzo[ph] project which is one of our Renewable Energy projects that qualifies for 100% bonus depreciation so some of this is in our non-utility business. But we see that the bonus depreciation modest enough that modest amount in combination with our increased capital spending will not impact the growth rate in the utilities.

headline: DTE Energy Co., 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2011
componenttextpreview: Could we just ballpark by saying look at your non-utility CapEx your utility CapEx roughly the same proportion?
componenttext: Could we just ballpark by saying look at your non-utility CapEx your utility CapEx roughly the same proportion?

headline: DTE Energy Co., 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think roughly that you're ballpark number.
componenttext: Yes. I think roughly that you're ballpark number.

headline: DTE Energy Co., 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2011
componenttextpreview: And then just anything happening on the political front with the new governor in place?
componenttext: And then just anything happening on the political front with the new governor in place?

headline: DTE Energy Co., 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2011
componenttextpreview: This is Gerry, Paul. I guess I'd just say that the new governor has got like most two governors do, slay the challenges out in front of him principally and focused on state budget and reform of the cost structures of the state. We know him very well. I kn
componenttext: This is Gerry, Paul. I guess I'd just say that the new governor has got like most two governors do, slay the challenges out in front of him principally and focused on state budget and reform of the cost structures of the state. We know him very well. I know him well personally. And he's a good guy, straight-forward, ethical guy. But I think his focus is going to be squarely on that energy really hasn't risen on the agenda of the new administration, because they got so much in their plate on other fronts, and I think that's likely to remain that way. So does that answer your question?

headline: DTE Energy Co., 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2011
componenttextpreview: Just a follow-up are the choice advocates getting in your direction at all?
componenttext: Just a follow-up are the choice advocates getting in your direction at all?

headline: DTE Energy Co., 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2011
componenttextpreview: No. I think if you probably look at some things in state political regulatory rags here in the state over the past few days that there's been some commentary on that. We also know the leadership of the House and the Senate and the energy committees and bo
componenttext: No. I think if you probably look at some things in state political regulatory rags here in the state over the past few days that there's been some commentary on that. We also know the leadership of the House and the Senate and the energy committees and both quite well, we know what their priorities are and I think, and you'll say they've set themselves and I think if you talk to them, this isn't one of their priorities for the energy agenda.

headline: DTE Energy Co., 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2011
componenttextpreview: And then on the list of things that kind of worry you Gerry, how much is our regeneration? How does that stack on the list?
componenttext: And then on the list of things that kind of worry you Gerry, how much is our regeneration? How does that stack on the list?

headline: DTE Energy Co., 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2011
componenttextpreview: I think, our philosophy and on the utility front is you got to give to receive. You got to earn the quality of your regulation. And so, the past year we've been striking with our regulators is we're going to work our tails off to manage customer affordabi
componenttext: I think, our philosophy and on the utility front is you got to give to receive. You got to earn the quality of your regulation. And so, the past year we've been striking with our regulators is we're going to work our tails off to manage customer affordability, and I think you see that for example, in our Detroit Edison rate filing where we worked hundreds of millions of dollars out of what the act might have been all with the nigh[ph] to reducing the impact on customers. The MichCon case being pulled was another case in point. So the approach we're trying to take with the regulators is to work jointly on the big things, and not spend a lot of time on things like ROE reduction and frankly feel that if we do a really good job on the big things, that we'll get fair treatment on that and other fronts.

headline: DTE Energy Co., 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2011
componenttextpreview: We'll take our next question from Steve Fleishman with Bank of America Merryll Lynch.
componenttext: We'll take our next question from Steve Fleishman with Bank of America Merryll Lynch.

componenttext: I guess this one follow-up question from what Paul just asked, just from a sensitivity standpoint, what is the impact of 100 bps sensitivity on ROE for the utilities? 10 bps or  however you have it?

componenttext: Yes, for Edison it's about $40 million, 41% and for MichCon it'd be about $10 million, so 10 bps could $4 million.

componenttext: And MichCon about quarter of that, so combined $5 million for the two.

headline: DTE Energy Co., 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2011
componenttextpreview: And then one other question on the choice cap, it sounds like it's not an issue, but how much request is there really are people wanting choice beyond the cap that's there? Is it 10% cap? is it only another few percent that want choice?
componenttext: And then one other question on the choice cap, it sounds like it's not an issue, but how much request is there really are people wanting choice beyond the cap that's there? Is it 10% cap? is it only another few percent that want choice?

headline: DTE Energy Co., 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2011
componenttextpreview: No. I think in this market, there would be more than a few percent, but I think, what the policymakers realize is that if you go back to just couple years ago, there was zero requests and choice was falling to zero and now there is a request for more than
componenttext: No. I think in this market, there would be more than a few percent, but I think, what the policymakers realize is that if you go back to just couple years ago, there was zero requests and choice was falling to zero and now there is a request for more than 10%. The whole point of the Cap is money markets are volatile and if you set policy kind of volatile commodity markets you don't have a policy. And I think our regulators and legislators understand that. So the reason I think it isn't high in their agenda, is for that reason. I think one person in particular who understands it is our Governor. It didn't take them long. He's an ex-businessman in particular, a high-tech businessman with a financial background. Took him about five minutes to come to the conclusion that "Oh! Well what people are looking for here, is just a free option  right?". And the answer is yes, and that's not a policy. So I think he understands the issue as do the leaders in the House and the Senate.

headline: DTE Energy Co., 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2011

headline: DTE Energy Co., 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2011
componenttextpreview: Let me take a correction, so I think what Dave was saying was that the highest prices in the market place right now are for oil and natural gas liquids. We do have those in our properties and we are making progress in continuing to improve our ability to
componenttext: Let me take a correction, so I think what Dave was saying was that the highest prices in the market place right now are for oil and natural gas liquids. We do have those in our properties and we are making progress in continuing to improve our ability to get those and get them economically, so it's really the timing of that, that will define the timing of sale. If you were to look at this year versus next year, we may see some modest monetizations this year, but we'd expect something larger would likely play out next year or beyond.

headline: DTE Energy Co., 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2011
componenttextpreview: So if you look over the past five years, both our cash flow and our earnings there are $40 million to $50 million a year. And so we talk about normal $40 million to $50 million is what we mean we said pretty consistently we're not going to grow that busin
componenttext: So if you look over the past five years, both our cash flow and our earnings there are $40 million to $50 million a year. And so we talk about normal $40 million to $50 million is what we mean we said pretty consistently we're not going to grow that business it provides us intelligence and cash. And that's it's role. It was $75 million two years ago and $6 million last year. We had a long period in 2010 were the markets just went dead, not only for us but everybody. About an eight month period, but in December and January and so far in February, we have seen the markets return to much more normal behavior within our operation. So that's a positive sign. It's not something you can project, it has to continue or will continue, but it certainly is a reversion back to more normal behavior from that, that eight-month dead period last year. And as Dave said, what we have this year is a range of 10% to 40% it's just in line with what we saw this past year at the low end and kind of a low-end of normal at the high-end so the midpoint is 25%, but we'd expect over time that we'd be able to achieve what we've seen over the past five years or so that $40 million to $50 million performance.

headline: DTE Energy Co., 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2011
componenttextpreview: And we'll take our next question from Paul Harrison with Liemar[ph] Associates.
componenttext: And we'll take our next question from Paul Harrison with Liemar[ph] Associates.

headline: DTE Energy Co., 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, one element you pointed out which is our renewable investments, which are as you can see on one of the slides is a significant piece of growth at Detroit Edison. That increase in rates happened as part of the legislation, and it is done. So there wi
componenttext: Well, one element you pointed out which is our renewable investments, which are as you can see on one of the slides is a significant piece of growth at Detroit Edison. That increase in rates happened as part of the legislation, and it is done. So there will be increases for that, so that's a good thing, because the second would be that as we continue to invest in one of the questions people might ask is how can you grow it 5% to 6% in your utility if you're not going at 5% to 6% in your rate structure? And what we're trying to do, first of all, the renewable [indiscernible] with that because of the way the legislature structured them, but secondly we're fighting hard on the Continuous Improvement front to manage our operating costs to a lower growth profile than that. The combination of the two are what we hope will allow us to moderate the rate increase profile.

headline: DTE Energy Co., 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2011
componenttextpreview: How regular and how much? So here's how we talk about it internally. We, very exclusively are telling our people from an affordability standpoint, hold off as long as we can, but we also don't want to hold off so long that the cases become complex or larg
componenttext: How regular and how much? So here's how we talk about it internally. We, very exclusively are telling our people from an affordability standpoint, hold off as long as we can, but we also don't want to hold off so long that the cases become complex or large. For us, the regulators or our customers. So striking that balance between regularity and health for us and workload and impact on our customers. So this pastor that meant that we've held off from our case in January and a filing in October to go but if you look forward, this is a heavy period of investment particularly in Emission  Controls where we've got almost $1 billion over the next three years, and that's going to imply that our rate base is going to be growing and we're going to need to get returns on that to stay healthy. So I expect to see us going in each year, but we'll use the philosophy I just described.

headline: DTE Energy Co., 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well you're right on the specifics on that one. You should talk to CMS we don't make specific about them, but I have read the orders and there was information that came in late so I think the commission was saying we've got some late information we want s
componenttext: Well you're right on the specifics on that one. You should talk to CMS we don't make specific about them, but I have read the orders and there was information that came in late so I think the commission was saying we've got some late information we want sometime to digest it. If you take it more broadly and our feel for things, I don't think it has any President, if you ask am I concerned about self-implementation or the structure generally, I'm not, I myself and other senior people have been up and to talk the commissioners recently and I think they remained committed to playing out that legislation in the right way. So I'm not concerned in terms of the President or tone or feel of things.

headline: DTE Energy Co., 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2011
componenttextpreview: The way those things play out is forward-looking, so they're always working on forward-looking year budgets. Doing impact studies on forward years. And if they change policy whether it's on renewables or things like REF, to my knowledge, they've never don
componenttext: The way those things play out is forward-looking, so they're always working on forward-looking year budgets. Doing impact studies on forward years. And if they change policy whether it's on renewables or things like REF, to my knowledge, they've never done it backward looking. They have the right to come in and audit things to make sure it played out according to the law and so forth, but they have never, in one of their real principle of tax policies, you said that  people need to be able to rely on it and invest against it, so the changes are forward-looking. So I do expect that there's going to be a lot of debate around energy tax provisions, renewable tax provisions. For example, something people are going to be talking about. I think they will remain, but just how large they are and so forth and we'll get plenty of discussion.

headline: DTE Energy Co., 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2011
componenttextpreview: And we'll take our next question from John Quilly[ph] with Canaccord Genuity.
componenttext: And we'll take our next question from John Quilly[ph] with Canaccord Genuity.

headline: DTE Energy Co., 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2011
componenttextpreview: So we are making good progress on it, it's ahead of schedule, on budget, we've got about 130,000 meters completed at the end of this past year, we expect 300,000 by the end of this year and the that's of a total of 600,000 meters. And what we've talk to t
componenttext: So we are making good progress on it, it's ahead of schedule, on budget, we've got about 130,000 meters completed at the end of this past year, we expect 300,000 by the end of this year and the that's of a total of 600,000 meters. And what we've talk to the commission about is that we want to take a stop at the end of 600,000 meters evaluate benefits, evaluate, we had a projected list of savings, step back and make sure that we're getting those. The other thing  that is true in this round of investment for us, we got a stimulus grant that brought down our net investment and brought down our the cost to customers so what we want to do then is evaluate based upon the savings that we are seeing, do we see savings to customers without help from the federal government, in other words if we need to carry full load, do these things pay for themselves and lower customer rates. And that's what we -- we'll take a pause to do that evaluation. The other thing we wanted the evaluate is the service improvements, these meters are going to allow us to do some things for customers that we've never been able to do like know before they know when they're out of power and typical example, people are off at work,  come home to find her power out. We'll know that and can get them back up and running before they ever knew they ever knew they were out of power. So there will be service improvements to it but general philosophy, we're going to take a stop and evaluate and see if we should go on.

headline: DTE Energy Co., 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2011
componenttextpreview: No. We are fully using, if I got your question right, we're on an investment path to utilize those funds that was described by the federal government and that's all working fine. And there is no contingency related to what we do in the future.
componenttext: No. We are fully using, if I got your question right, we're on an investment path to utilize those funds that was described by the federal government and that's all working fine. And there is no contingency related to what we do in the future.

headline: DTE Energy Co., 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2011
componenttextpreview: We'll take our next question with Mark Hornett[ph] with  MorningStar.
componenttext: We'll take our next question with Mark Hornett[ph] with  MorningStar.

headline: DTE Energy Co., 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2011
componenttextpreview: I think it's two things. Post-crisis, I think there was a stronger mindset about use of energy in homes and commercial businesses, the other thing is, that we are investing pretty heavily around conservation And I think there's an impact about. And frankl
componenttext: I think it's two things. Post-crisis, I think there was a stronger mindset about use of energy in homes and commercial businesses, the other thing is, that we are investing pretty heavily around conservation And I think there's an impact about. And frankly, we want that impact. The other conversation we have as a company is managing customer bills with a focus on bill size. And so we're looking at the combined residential gas electric bill and try to manage it down because we feel if we manage it down the investments we're making will be received a lot better. And so, that decline in residential average use, we welcome and our working to make it happen.

headline: DTE Energy Co., 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2011
componenttextpreview: Housing or population? We saw -- I guess the best thing to do is probably customers, we saw a slight decline in customer count during the heart of the crisis. And I don't have a trend on that now the economy peaks back up and so forth. Would expect to see
componenttext: Housing or population? We saw -- I guess the best thing to do is probably customers, we saw a slight decline in customer count during the heart of the crisis. And I don't have a trend on that now the economy peaks back up and so forth. Would expect to see probably that reverse and trend the other way.

headline: DTE Energy Co., 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2011
componenttextpreview: We don't have any plan that we've announced so we don't have anything specific on that yet.
componenttext: We don't have any plan that we've announced so we don't have anything specific on that yet.

headline: DTE Energy Co., 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, like we said in an interesting position relative to what you described, because Michigan is a big storage market, and so we actually have seen this change in our gas flow dynamics impacting pipes that you thought were going to flow one way people ar
componenttext: Well, like we said in an interesting position relative to what you described, because Michigan is a big storage market, and so we actually have seen this change in our gas flow dynamics impacting pipes that you thought were going to flow one way people are talking about flowing the other direction or mixed flows, one direction one part of year and another direction another one part of the year as we fill storage, for example. So yes. What people are talking about is real, if you asked is that all figured out yet, no. It's all pretty dynamic end-users are trying to take stock of the significant change of these change at this basis and send what that means for pipe flows and storage utilization, and we really do, do look at our Millennium Pipeline for example, and the connection of that back to Canada to a big storage base in Michigan, we are one of the player that would potentially see that sort of impact. And that could be good impact, but it's the market is still working all that out.

headline: DTE Energy Co., 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2011
componenttextpreview: And we'll take our next question was Danielle Seeds[ph] with Dueback Research[ph].
componenttext: And we'll take our next question was Danielle Seeds[ph] with Dueback Research[ph].

headline: DTE Energy Co., 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2011
componenttextpreview: This is Dave, Danielle. The first answer would be when we originally said $100 million to $200 million a year that never involved public issuance, that was always going to be through dripper or pension plans. And as we've said now, that's all turned off b
componenttext: This is Dave, Danielle. The first answer would be when we originally said $100 million to $200 million a year that never involved public issuance, that was always going to be through dripper or pension plans. And as we've said now, that's all turned off because the number is zero this year, we're going to work hard to see if we could drive that number down to zero next year. And I have no plans right now for '13 because as we've indicated, we are not only working on cash flows but we still have that, to get that '13 timeframe, that now circles back to when do we see monetization starting to happen on the Barnett. So it's very possible '13 could be zero also, but we'll have too wait and see how that plays out.

headline: DTE Energy Co., 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2011
componenttextpreview: And we'll take our next question from Leon Devoe[ph] with Catapult[ph]   Capital Management.
componenttext: And we'll take our next question from Leon Devoe[ph] with Catapult[ph]   Capital Management.

headline: DTE Energy Co., 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2011
componenttextpreview: So on the first question, most of our coke volume now is contract a little bit available on the spot stock market but not much, we've been working to get those fully contracted so the earnings stability is there and in terms of total tons I don't have tha
componenttext: So on the first question, most of our coke volume now is contract a little bit available on the spot stock market but not much, we've been working to get those fully contracted so the earnings stability is there and in terms of total tons I don't have that in my fingertips, but it's on the order of a couple million tons by the time you put out total position together. If you need that, we could get that for you. In terms of being monetized, we haven't looked at it but it could be something, For example, if a steel company wanted to manage their coke prices and coke availability and so forth could have interest in and down the road, that turned out to be the right value decision when we look at it short have we had anybody approach us on it or had any discussions on it, no.

headline: DTE Energy Co., 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2011
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] And we'll take our next question from Ashar Khan with Visio.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] And we'll take our next question from Ashar Khan with Visio.

headline: DTE Energy Co., 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2011
componenttextpreview: I just had a query, is there an area concerned Dave you mentioned in your remarks that's one of the reasons you are kind of like took off the gas case is there a concern that you have that is not sustainable? Just trying to get a better context of your re
componenttext: I just had a query, is there an area concerned Dave you mentioned in your remarks that's one of the reasons you are kind of like took off the gas case is there a concern that you have that is not sustainable? Just trying to get a better context of your remarks earlier on?

headline: DTE Energy Co., 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2011
componenttextpreview: No, actually I'm not sure exactly what you're referring to because our  pulling the gas case had nothing to do with concerns about return on equity. We filed the case and as any other case over time, after we filed it, some of the assumptions started to c
componenttext: No, actually I'm not sure exactly what you're referring to because our  pulling the gas case had nothing to do with concerns about return on equity. We filed the case and as any other case over time, after we filed it, some of the assumptions started to change and the factors we looked at the amount of money what we would need on the rate increase to hit our targeted earnings was much smaller. And we stood back, and looked at it and said we know we could actually pull this case and go after cost reductions and hit our objectives and that the same time, it's one less case for us and the commission and it's the right thing for customers to do. And then we can put our energy and focus together on the Detroit Edison case where there's a lot more economics so this is more about that overtime, the number small enough we started asking ourselves a question where are we pursuing the case versus just going back to what we do really well which is work on Continuous Improvement and cost. And I think Gerry addressed that overall our view right now is that in the Edison case, we filed for 11 and then eight, we believe that our position on that is supportable and we're going to pursue that in the case and we think there's other, much larger value drivers for customers that we will be talking to the commission about in the way we file that could we can make it a win-win for us and for customers ROE's one of them.

headline: DTE Energy Co., 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2011
