headline: DTE Energy Co., 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2011
componenttextpreview: I guess I just got a little confused earlier on the Barnett discussion. The sale of the property, is that something that's probably going to happen in 2011? Or is it going to be multiyear? How is that going to work?
componenttext: I guess I just got a little confused earlier on the Barnett discussion. The sale of the property, is that something that's probably going to happen in 2011? Or is it going to be multiyear? How is that going to work?

headline: DTE Energy Co., 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2011
componenttextpreview: Let me take a crack at that. So I think what Dave was saying is that the highest prices in the market place right now are for oil and natural gas liquids. We do have those in our properties, and we're making progress in continuing to improve our ability t
componenttext: Let me take a crack at that. So I think what Dave was saying is that the highest prices in the market place right now are for oil and natural gas liquids. We do have those in our properties, and we're making progress in continuing to improve our ability to get those and get them economically. So it's really the timing of that, that will define the timing of sale. If you were to look at this year versus next year, we may see some modest monetizations this year. But we'd expect that something larger would likely play out next year or beyond.

headline: DTE Energy Co., 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2011
componenttextpreview: And then just a second question on the Trading business. I guess part of your long-term 5% to 6% there assumes trading returns back to normal levels. What are those normal levels? And I mean, what's kind of the driver I guess to get it back up there?
componenttext: And then just a second question on the Trading business. I guess part of your long-term 5% to 6% there assumes trading returns back to normal levels. What are those normal levels? And I mean, what's kind of the driver I guess to get it back up there?

headline: DTE Energy Co., 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2011
componenttextpreview: So if you look over the past five years, both our cash flow and our earnings there, are $40 million to $50 million a year. And so we talk about normal $40 million to $50 million is what we mean, we've said pretty consistently, we're not looking going to g
componenttext: So if you look over the past five years, both our cash flow and our earnings there, are $40 million to $50 million a year. And so we talk about normal $40 million to $50 million is what we mean, we've said pretty consistently, we're not looking going to grow that business. It provides us intelligence and cash, and that's its role. It was $75 million two years ago and $6 million last year. We had a long period in 2010 where the markets just went dead, not only for us but everybody, about an eight month period. But in December and January and so far in February, we have seen the markets return to much more normal behavior within our operation. So that's a positive sign. It's not something you can project, has to continue or will continue. But it certainly is a reversion back to more normal behavior from that, that eight-month dead period last year. And as Dave said, what we have this year is a range of $10 million to $40 million. It's just in line with what we saw this past year at the low-end, and kind of a low-end of normal at the high-end, so the midpoint is $25 million. But we'd expect over time that we'd be able to achieve what we've seen over the past five years or so, that $40 million to $50 million performance.

headline: DTE Energy Co., 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2011
componenttextpreview: And we'll take our next question from Paul Patterson with Glenrock Associates.
componenttext: And we'll take our next question from Paul Patterson with Glenrock Associates.

headline: DTE Energy Co., 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2011
componenttextpreview: I wondered, just sort of a follow-up on the rate impact because you guys mentioned that there's a lot of investment, but it seems that there's considerable amount of renewables and energy conservation. And you guys have been doing a lot in cost savings an
componenttext: I wondered, just sort of a follow-up on the rate impact because you guys mentioned that there's a lot of investment, but it seems that there's considerable amount of renewables and energy conservation. And you guys have been doing a lot in cost savings and what have you. So how should we think -- you obviously mentioned affordability and what have you, so how should we think about how much rate relief you'll actually be seeking with this rather large capital investment?

headline: DTE Energy Co., 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, one element you pointed out, which is our renewable investments, which are as you can see on one of the slides is a significant piece of growth at Detroit Edison. That increase in rates happened as part of the legislation, and it's done. So there wo
componenttext: Well, one element you pointed out, which is our renewable investments, which are as you can see on one of the slides is a significant piece of growth at Detroit Edison. That increase in rates happened as part of the legislation, and it's done. So there won't be increases for that. So that's a good thing because the second would be that as we continue to invest. And one of the questions people might ask is, well how can you grow it 5% to 6% in your utility if you're not growing at 5% to 6% in your rate structure? And what we're trying to do, first of all, the renewables helped with that because of the way the legislature structured them. But secondly we're fighting hard on the Continuous Improvement front to manage our operating costs to a lower growth profile than that. The combination of the two are what we hope will allow us to moderate the rate increase profile.

headline: DTE Energy Co., 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2011
componenttextpreview: So I mean when we're thinking about you going in for rate cases, I guess should we think of them as still being sort an annual thing? I mean you have your full blast them like you mentioned. I'm just sort of wondering, I mean how should we think about the
componenttext: So I mean when we're thinking about you going in for rate cases, I guess should we think of them as still being sort an annual thing? I mean you have your full blast them like you mentioned. I'm just sort of wondering, I mean how should we think about the sort of -- how much sort of regulatory relief we're going to be looking at?

headline: DTE Energy Co., 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2011
componenttextpreview: How regular? How much? So here's how we talk about it internally. We, very explicitly, are telling our people, and we, from an affordability standpoint, hold off as long as we can. But we also don't want to hold off so long that the cases become complex o
componenttext: How regular? How much? So here's how we talk about it internally. We, very explicitly, are telling our people, and we, from an affordability standpoint, hold off as long as we can. But we also don't want to hold off so long that the cases become complex or large. For us, the regulators are our customers. So it's striking that balance between regularity and health for us, and workload and impact on our customers. So this past year that meant that we held off from a case in January until a filing in October. But if you look forward, this is a heavy period of investment, particularly in Emission  Controls, where we've got almost $1 billion over the next three years. And that's going to imply that our rate base is going to be growing, and we're going to need to get returns on that to stay healthy. So I expect to see us going in each year, but we'll use the philosophy I just described.

headline: DTE Energy Co., 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2011
componenttextpreview: There's another utility in Michigan that sort of have their self-implementation situation? I know that's a specific thing to them, but any flavor or change with respect to the commission at all, in terms of concerns about rates or what have you?
componenttext: There's another utility in Michigan that sort of have their self-implementation situation? I know that's a specific thing to them, but any flavor or change with respect to the commission at all, in terms of concerns about rates or what have you?

headline: DTE Energy Co., 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well you're right on the specifics on that one, you should talk to CMS, and we make a habit of not saying anything specific about them, but I have read the orders and there was information that came in late so I think the commission was saying we've got s
componenttext: Well you're right on the specifics on that one, you should talk to CMS, and we make a habit of not saying anything specific about them, but I have read the orders and there was information that came in late so I think the commission was saying we've got some late information, we want some time to digest it. If you take it more broadly and our feel for things, I don't think it has any precedent. If you ask, am I concerned about self-implementation or the structure generally, I'm not. I, personally and other senior people have been up to talk the commissioners recently, and I think they remained committed to playing out that legislation in the right way. So I'm not concerned in terms of precedent or tone or feel of things.

headline: DTE Energy Co., 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2011
componenttextpreview: Then just finally, there's a lot of talk in Congress about tax expenditures as being a means of budget discipline so to speak. I don't know how to put it. But whatever, do you see any exposure, you mentioned how the steel thing didn't work out as you kind
componenttext: Then just finally, there's a lot of talk in Congress about tax expenditures as being a means of budget discipline so to speak. I don't know how to put it. But whatever, do you see any exposure, you mentioned how the steel thing didn't work out as you kind of expected, should we be concerned about any specific tax situation that you see being potentially under assault or being changed perhaps with of the new Congress and the new sort of budget discipline that's sort of showing up there?

headline: DTE Energy Co., 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2011
componenttextpreview: The way those things play out is forward looking. So they're always working on forward-year budgets and doing impact studies on forward years. And if they change policy, whether it's on renewables or things like REF, to my knowledge, they've never done it
componenttext: The way those things play out is forward looking. So they're always working on forward-year budgets and doing impact studies on forward years. And if they change policy, whether it's on renewables or things like REF, to my knowledge, they've never done it backward looking. They have the right to come in and audit things to make sure that it played out according to the law and so forth, but they have never. And one of the real principles of tax policy is if you said it, and people need to be able to rely on it and invest against it, so the changes are forward looking. So I do expect that there's going to be a lot of debate around energy tax provisions, renewable tax provisions. For example, there will be something that people are going to talk about. I think they'll remain, but just how large they are and so forth, will get plenty of discussion.

headline: DTE Energy Co., 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2011
componenttextpreview: And we'll take our next question from John Quealy with Canaccord Genuity.
componenttext: And we'll take our next question from John Quealy with Canaccord Genuity.

headline: DTE Energy Co., 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2011
componenttextpreview: It's Mark Sigal for John I was just wondering if you guys could talk a little bit about the smart meter program, your assessment of how that's going so far. And perhaps talk about the process for evaluating, expanding beyond your initial commitment throug
componenttext: It's Mark Sigal for John I was just wondering if you guys could talk a little bit about the smart meter program, your assessment of how that's going so far. And perhaps talk about the process for evaluating, expanding beyond your initial commitment through next year.

headline: DTE Energy Co., 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2011
componenttextpreview: So we're making good progress on it. It's ahead of schedule, on budget, we've got about 130,000 meters completed at the end of this past year, expect to have 300,000 in by the end of this year, and that's of a total of 600,000. And what we've talked to th
componenttext: So we're making good progress on it. It's ahead of schedule, on budget, we've got about 130,000 meters completed at the end of this past year, expect to have 300,000 in by the end of this year, and that's of a total of 600,000. And what we've talked to the commission about is that we want to take a stop at the end of 600,000 meters, evaluate benefits, evaluate -- we had a projected list of savings, we're going to step back and make sure that we're getting those. The other thing that is true in this round of investments for us is that we got a stimulus grant. So that brought down our net investment, and it brought down the cost to customers. So what we want to do then is to evaluate based upon the savings that we are seeing. Do we see savings to customers without help from the federal government, in other words if we need to carry the full load, do these things pay for themselves and lower customer rates? And that's what we -- we'll take a pause to do that evaluation. The other thing that we want to evaluate is the service improvement, so these meters are going to allow us to do some things for customers that we've never been able to do like know before they know when they're out of power, and typical example, people are off at work,  come home to find they're power out. We'll know that and can get them back up and running before they ever knew they were out of power. So there will be service improvements too, but general philosophy, we're going to take a stop and evaluate and see if we should go on.

headline: DTE Energy Co., 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2011
componenttextpreview: And does the stimulus money -- is there an embedded provision in that, that says when you've got to make that decision or have your funds allocated by?
componenttext: And does the stimulus money -- is there an embedded provision in that, that says when you've got to make that decision or have your funds allocated by?

headline: DTE Energy Co., 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2011
componenttextpreview: No, we are fully using the -- if I got your question right, we're on an investment path to utilize those funds that was described in federal government, and that's all working fine. And there is no contingency related to what we do in the future.
componenttext: No, we are fully using the -- if I got your question right, we're on an investment path to utilize those funds that was described in federal government, and that's all working fine. And there is no contingency related to what we do in the future.

headline: DTE Energy Co., 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2011
componenttextpreview: We'll take our next question with Mark Barnett with Morningstar.
componenttext: We'll take our next question with Mark Barnett with Morningstar.

headline: DTE Energy Co., 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2011
componenttextpreview: First, on the sales side, I know the coupling is taking care of the earnings and cash flow there, but can you give me just a little bit of commentary on commercial and residential sales. Obviously weren't as strong as industrial, and maybe what's going th
componenttext: First, on the sales side, I know the coupling is taking care of the earnings and cash flow there, but can you give me just a little bit of commentary on commercial and residential sales. Obviously weren't as strong as industrial, and maybe what's going there, a little color around that?

headline: DTE Energy Co., 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2011
componenttextpreview: I think it's two things. At post-crisis, I think there was a stronger mindset about use of energy in homes and commercial businesses. The other thing is, that we are investing pretty heavily around conservation. And I think there's an impact to that. And
componenttext: I think it's two things. At post-crisis, I think there was a stronger mindset about use of energy in homes and commercial businesses. The other thing is, that we are investing pretty heavily around conservation. And I think there's an impact to that. And frankly, we want that impact. The other conversation we have in the company is managing customer bills with a focus on bill size, and so we are looking at the combined residential gas electric bill and try to manage it down because we feel if we manage it down, the investments we're making will be received a lot better. And so, that decline in residential average use, we welcome and are working to make happen.

headline: DTE Energy Co., 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2011
componenttextpreview: So you don't see a lot of -- I mean, I guess what's sort of the housing situation in your service territories? I'm not really up-to-date with that information.
componenttext: So you don't see a lot of -- I mean, I guess what's sort of the housing situation in your service territories? I'm not really up-to-date with that information.

headline: DTE Energy Co., 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2011
componenttextpreview: Housing or population? I guess the best way to do is probably customers. We saw a slight decline in customer count during the heart of the crisis. And I don't have a trend on that now. As the economy picks back up and so forth, we'd expect to see probably
componenttext: Housing or population? I guess the best way to do is probably customers. We saw a slight decline in customer count during the heart of the crisis. And I don't have a trend on that now. As the economy picks back up and so forth, we'd expect to see probably that reverse and trend the other way.

headline: DTE Energy Co., 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2011
componenttextpreview: Was there a plan this year for MichCon filing to replace what you delayed last year?
componenttext: Was there a plan this year for MichCon filing to replace what you delayed last year?

headline: DTE Energy Co., 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2011
componenttextpreview: We don't have any plan that we've announced, so we don't have anything specific on that yet.
componenttext: We don't have any plan that we've announced, so we don't have anything specific on that yet.

headline: DTE Energy Co., 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2011
componenttextpreview: Just one more quick question, it's more on a general big picture. Couple of infrastructure pipeline companies around the Marcellus have been talking about the opportunity to ship gas back west and north and onwards eventually to Canada, what with the high
componenttext: Just one more quick question, it's more on a general big picture. Couple of infrastructure pipeline companies around the Marcellus have been talking about the opportunity to ship gas back west and north and onwards eventually to Canada, what with the higher gas prices up there. And I'm wondering where you guys sit at the pipe, you might have some insight to that, whether that makes sense and how that might affect your gas purchases going forward?

headline: DTE Energy Co., 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, look we sit in an interesting position relative to what you described because Michigan is a big storage market. And so we actually have seen this change in our gas flow dynamics impacting-- pipes that you thought were going to flow one way people ar
componenttext: Well, look we sit in an interesting position relative to what you described because Michigan is a big storage market. And so we actually have seen this change in our gas flow dynamics impacting-- pipes that you thought were going to flow one way people are talking about flowing the other direction or mixed flows, one direction one part of year, another direction another one part of the year as we fill storage, for example. So yes. What people are talking about is real, if you ask is that all figured out yet, no. It's still pretty dynamic, and end users are trying to take stock of the significant change that these shale basins have created and what that means for pipe flows and storage utilization. And we really do, you look at our Millennium Pipeline for example, and the connection of that back to Canada to a big storage base in Michigan, we're one of the players that would potentially see that sort of impact. And that could be a good impact, but it's the market is still working all that out.

headline: DTE Energy Co., 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2011
componenttextpreview: And we'll take our next question was Daniele Seitz with Dudack Research.
componenttext: And we'll take our next question was Daniele Seitz with Dudack Research.

headline: DTE Energy Co., 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2011
componenttextpreview: Just one on the equity issuance, you are still using a DRIP program?  How much does that provide, and do you anticipate the new equity issue to be in 2013 for sure?
componenttext: Just one on the equity issuance, you are still using a DRIP program?  How much does that provide, and do you anticipate the new equity issue to be in 2013 for sure?

headline: DTE Energy Co., 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2011
componenttextpreview: This is Dave, Daniele. The first answer would be when we originally said $100 million to $200 million a year, that never involved public issuance, that was always going to be through DRIP or pension plans. And as we said, now that's all turned off because
componenttext: This is Dave, Daniele. The first answer would be when we originally said $100 million to $200 million a year, that never involved public issuance, that was always going to be through DRIP or pension plans. And as we said, now that's all turned off because the number is zero this year. We're going to work hard to see if we can drive that number down to zero next year. And I have no plans right now for '13 because as we've indicated, we are not only working on cash flows, but we still have that, you get onto that '13 timeframe, that now circles back to when do we see monetization starting to happen in the Barnett. So it's very possible '13 could be zero also, but we'll have to wait and see how that plays out.

headline: DTE Energy Co., 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2011
componenttextpreview: And we'll take our next question from Leon Dubov with Catapult Capital Management.
componenttext: And we'll take our next question from Leon Dubov with Catapult Capital Management.

headline: DTE Energy Co., 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2011
componenttextpreview: I was wondering if you can give me a little bit of metrics around your coke batteries business in terms of what kind of volumes you of guys do there? And sort of a follow-up to that with robust pricing we're seeing for met coal, is this an asset that coul
componenttext: I was wondering if you can give me a little bit of metrics around your coke batteries business in terms of what kind of volumes you of guys do there? And sort of a follow-up to that with robust pricing we're seeing for met coal, is this an asset that could potentially also be monetized?

headline: DTE Energy Co., 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2011
componenttextpreview: So on the first question, most of our, essentially all of our coke volume now is contracted, we have a little bit available in the spot market but not much. We've been working to get those fully contracted, so the earnings stability is there. And in terms
componenttext: So on the first question, most of our, essentially all of our coke volume now is contracted, we have a little bit available in the spot market but not much. We've been working to get those fully contracted, so the earnings stability is there. And in terms of total tons I don't have that at my fingertips, but it's on the order of I think a couple of million tons by the time you put our total position together. But If you need that, we could get that for you. In terms of being monetized, we haven't looked at it, but it could be something, For example, at a steel company, you wanted to manage their coke prices and coke availability and so forth, could have interest in, and down the road that turned out to be the right value decision whatever you look at it, sure. Have we had anybody approach us on it or had any discussions on it, no.

headline: DTE Energy Co., 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2011
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] And we'll take our next question from Ashar Khan with Visium.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] And we'll take our next question from Ashar Khan with Visium.

headline: DTE Energy Co., 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2011
componenttextpreview: I just had a query, is there an ROE concern? Dave you mentioned a little bit in your remarks that, that's one of the reasons you are kind of like you took off, I guess, gas case. Is there a concern that you have that this is not sustainable, or just tryin
componenttext: I just had a query, is there an ROE concern? Dave you mentioned a little bit in your remarks that, that's one of the reasons you are kind of like you took off, I guess, gas case. Is there a concern that you have that this is not sustainable, or just trying to get a better context of your remarks earlier on?

headline: DTE Energy Co., 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2011
componenttextpreview: No, actually I'm not sure exactly what you're referring to because at pulling the gas case had nothing to do with concerns about return on equity. We've filed the case and as any other case over time, after we filed it, some of the assumptions started to
componenttext: No, actually I'm not sure exactly what you're referring to because at pulling the gas case had nothing to do with concerns about return on equity. We've filed the case and as any other case over time, after we filed it, some of the assumptions started to change and the factors we looked at said the amount of money what we would need on the rate increase to hit our targeted earnings was much smaller. And we stood back, and looked at it, and said we could actually pull this case and go after cost reductions and hit our objectives and at the same time, it's one less case for us in the commission, and it's the right thing for customers to do. And then we can put our energy and focus together on the Detroit Edison case where there's a lot more economics. So this is more about that over time the number got small enough, we started asking ourselves the question why are we pursuing a case versus just going back to what we do really well, which is work on Continuous Improvement and cost. And I think Gerry addressed that overall, our ROE view right now is that in the Edison case, we filed for 11 1/8. We believe that our position on that is supportable, and we're going to pursue that in the case. And we think there's other, much larger value drivers for customers that we will be talking to the commission about, and the way that we filed that case that can make it a win-win for us and for customers and that ROE is one of them.

headline: DTE Energy Co., 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2011
componenttextpreview: And that concludes today's question-and-answer session. At this time, I'll turn conference back over to our presenters today for any additional or closing remarks.
componenttext: And that concludes today's question-and-answer session. At this time, I'll turn conference back over to our presenters today for any additional or closing remarks.

headline: DTE Energy Co., 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, no closing remarks. I just want to thank you all for your time and interest this morning. We look forward to keeping you posted on progress as things go on this year. Thanks very much.
componenttext: Well, no closing remarks. I just want to thank you all for your time and interest this morning. We look forward to keeping you posted on progress as things go on this year. Thanks very much.

headline: DTE Energy Co., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: Good day, ladies and gentlemen. Welcome to the DTE Energy First Quarter 2011 Earnings Release Conference. Please note that today's call is being recorded. At this time, I would like to turn things over to Mr. Dave Meador. Please go ahead, sir.
componenttext: Good day, ladies and gentlemen. Welcome to the DTE Energy First Quarter 2011 Earnings Release Conference. Please note that today's call is being recorded. At this time, I would like to turn things over to Mr. Dave Meador. Please go ahead, sir.

headline: DTE Energy Co., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: Okay. Thank you, Lisa. Good morning, and welcome to our first quarter conference call. Before we get started, I encourage you to read the Safe Harbor statement on Page 2, including the reference to forward-looking statements.With me this morning are Pet
componenttext:
Okay. Thank you, Lisa. Good morning, and welcome to our first quarter conference call. Before we get started, I encourage you to read the Safe Harbor statement on Page 2, including the reference to forward-looking statements.
With me this morning are Peter Oleksiak, Nick Khouri and Mark Rolling. I also have members of the leadership team available for Q&A if necessary.
Let me start with an overview on Slide 5. We have plans that will provide 5% to 6%  earnings growth and with both with our dividend of $2.24 per share, that provides a very attractive to shareholder return of 9% to 10%. This is offset with a key purity of maintaining a strong balance sheet. Our utility growth is driven by a federal and state mandates which even after aggressive cost management, a capital efficiency work will still generate 5%  to 6% earnings growth.
The utility plans are supported by a constructive regulatory structure and our cost savings are a tool to allow us to earn our authorized returns. We continue to focus on operational excellence and customer satisfaction. And as an example of that, our complaints to the Michigan Public Service Commission are down by another third this year. And our focus on procurement in Michigan has about 40% of our annual $1.1 billion spend driven to Michigan as we focus on helping drive Michigan's economy forward.
We also have meaningful growth opportunities in our Non-Utility businesses. The AGA Financial Conference is coming up here in May and Gerry Anderson will be there with updates on the Power & Industrial business, including an update on the REF business line and in our midstream business.
Now turning to Slide 6 is an overview for the quarter. We are a $1.11 per share in an operating earnings and we're right where we want to be in order to deliver your guidance of $3.40 to $3.70 per share. The 2 utilities are at 11%  return on equity last year and they remain on track to do the same this year. Yesterday, the Public Service Commission issued an order regarding self implementation, which was in line with our expectations and our plans. We have proposed several options to the commission in our original piece filings, which would get to you to the same interim economics of $230 million. The commission shows the option of $107 million in interim rates by not resetting the base rates for choice and the continuation of the choice tracker. And when you put this together, it gets you back to the same outcome of $230 million in economics. This was a result of the collaborative effort with the staff, and we are pleased with the constructive outcome.
Both power, industrial and gas pipelines and storage are also right on plan for the year. And just to note on the development side, we have entered into a letter of intent to Southwestern Energy to construct the lateral pipe, which we have referred to in our IR our materials as our Bluestone project. Bluestone will be a wholly owned DTE pipeline connecting to both Millennium and to the Tennessee pipeline and will transport gas from Southwestern's Marcellus Shale acreage. In terms of this arrangement are being negotiated right now as we work out a definitive agreement and Gerry Anderson will provide an update on this project at AGA.
Peter will take you through the details in a moment in Energy Trading, but Energy Trading is tracking economically to our guidance target. This quarters accounting earnings reflect timing within the year, and we continue to be comfortable with our total your guidance for Energy Trading. So overall, we're up to a very good start for the year. Our balance sheet is also right where we wanted to be and cash from operations was $700 million. We also have accelerated the timing of some of our wind projects with increasing our capital spending of about $300 million for the year. Although this increased to our 2011 CapEx guidance we provided earlier in the year, it is within our renewable energy plan, which is have been approved by the commission and Nick will take you through the details of the wind project on the capital side. With that, overview, let me turn it over to Peter, who will take you through the quarter.

headline: DTE Energy Co., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Dave. Good morning to everyone. I'd like to start with Slide 8 in the first quarter earnings results. For the quarter, DTE's operating earnings was $1.11. I'd like to remind everyone that a reconciliation to the GAAP reported earnings is contained
componenttext:
Thanks, Dave. Good morning to everyone. I'd like to start with Slide 8 in the first quarter earnings results. For the quarter, DTE's operating earnings was $1.11. I'd like to remind everyone that a reconciliation to the GAAP reported earnings is contained in the appendix. $0.57 and Michigan which typically have the strong first quarter came in at $0.49. The 9 utility segments combined earned $0.15. The drivers for the nonutility first quarter results were gas storage and pipeline at $0.9. Our industrial projects at $0.06, Energy Trading at $0.01 and commercial gas production at $0.01 loss. Finally, corporate and other had a loss of $0.10 in the quarter. 
Let's move to Slide 9 and the summary of the quarter-to-quarter performance by segment.
Our earnings for consolidated DTE Energy are down $41 million for the quarter. Together, our core utilities, Edison and MichCon had $10 million of an earnings over to prior year and additional details in the 2 utility companies later in the presentation.
Our Non-Utility segments are down $42 million, primarily driven by our Energy Trading segment down $36 million, which had historically high income in the first quarter last year. I'll provide more color on the Energy Trading performance in a moment. Power & Industrial projects was down $8 million, resulting from non-repeating last year from the steel energy fuels tax credit and favorable coal pricing.
Gas Storage and Pipeline and Unconventional Gas Production earnings are up slightly from the prior year. Corporate & Other was down $9 million from last year due to a onetime 2010 tax benefit. Before I move from this page, just a few more words on the Energy Trading's first quarter performance. As you recall, we lowered the income range in our 2011 guidance for the trading business to a midpoint of $25 million, down by a more historical average of $40 million to $50 million We are on track to achieve the midpoint of guidance for the segment in 2011.
The first quarter is off to a strong start for new transactions. On Page 21 of the appendix, we provided our spinach be delicious both economic and accounting performance. On that page, you will see that we have $22 million of economic income, which is not recognized yet for accounting purposes. There are numerous transactions we entered into in the first quarter that will not start recognizing income until the physical delivery of the power or gas.  An example of this is gas transaction where the gas delivered starting in the fourth quarter. We expect a good portion of the 22 mine that flow through operating earnings in the fourth quarter this year.
As a result, the next 2 quarters of accounting income could be relatively flat for Energy Trading business.
Now I like to go through some quarterly details of the utility companies beginning with Detroit Edison on Slide 10. Operating earnings for Detroit Edison was $97 million, up $6 million from the prior year. Margin for the quarter was up $8 million, driven primarily by energy efficiency incentives recorded in the first quarter 2011 after receiving a favorable order in our efficiency reconciliation related to achieving prior year incentives. Even though we have revenue decoupling with our electric utility, we still closely monitor underlying electrical load. Overall, temperature in our number was up 1 percent in the quarter. We continue to see positive signs of economic improvement in Michigan translating into an increased sales.
On the expense side, O&M was higher as a result of timing power plant maintenance and onetime benefit savings realized in 2010. In addition, in 2011, we have experience lower interest expense in favorable first quarter of 2011 property tax settlement at Detroit Edison.
Moving onto Page 11, a review of MichCon's performance. As mentioned earlier, the first quarter is typically the strongest in the seasonal Gas Utility business. Operating earnings for MichCon was $83 million, up $4 million from the prior year. The primary driver was $16 million of favorable weather impacts as the quarter saw 14%  pickup in heating degree days compared to 2010. Margin that other than was down $9 million primarily driven by the fact that a final rates in the June 2010 order, which carried into the first quarter of 2011 are lower than the south implementation rates executed in the first quarter of 2010.  In addition, maintenance expense were up due to an increase in schedule in main service repairs. That concludes an update on our earnings for the quarter.I'd like to turn discussion over to Nick Khouri who will cover cash flow and capital expenditures.

headline: DTE Energy Co., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Peter, and good morning, everyone. As always, improved cash flow and balance sheet strength remains a key priority for management and board of directors. To the first three months of this year, DTE Energy's cash and balance sheet metrics are on tr
componenttext:
Thanks, Peter, and good morning, everyone. As always, improved cash flow and balance sheet strength remains a key priority for management and board of directors. To the first three months of this year, DTE Energy's cash and balance sheet metrics are on track. In fact, nearly equal for the historical strong year we saw in 2010. 
Page 13 summarizes our balance sheet metrics. We expect to end this year within our targeted leverage in cash flow ranges.  In addition, we have made significant progress towards our 2011 funding requirements. We have completed our pension plan funding earlier this year than in past years, and we do not foresee the need for new equity in 2011. Liquidity remains strong with no expiring credit facilities until 2012.
Page 14 provides an overview of DTE's keys cash flow in the first quarter of this year versus the same period last year. Cash from operations, adjusted of for the early pension contribution was about on par with a strong internal cash seen last year.  As expected, capital was up a bit compared to last year, which I will detail in just a minute. On to net cash reached approximately a positive $300 million in the first quarter of 2011. As in prior years, net cash is not equal across the four quarters of the year both working capital requirements and capital spending is back loaded towards the end of the year.
Page 15 detail first quarter capital spending. Year-to-date capital spending is about on par with last year for MichCon and the Non-Utility business. Capital is higher in Detroit Edison, reflecting an expected increase in environmental spending in the timing of plant outages.
Page 16 shows our revised guidance for 2011 cash and capital. The only change from the original guidance is higher renewable investments at Detroit Edison. As Dave mentioned, we were presented with an opportunity to accelerate the timing of our wind investment in Michigan. Renewable capital in 2011 is now projected at $350 million, up from the original guidance of $50 million.  Expense renewable investments at Detroit Edison are funded with the preexisting surcharge, a new capital can be supported without an increase in customer rates while still maintaining our balance sheet targets.
In summary, DTE's cash and balance sheet targets are on track with year-to-date actuals nearing the historically storage year we saw in 2010, allowing us to accelerate our investment in the Renewable portfolio of Detroit Edison.
Now let me turn it back to Dave to wrap up.

headline: DTE Energy Co., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Nick. Let me wrap up on Slide 18. We're off to their good start in 2011 as we outlined group in on plan and we are targeting the midpoint of guidance for the year. As you can see, we're making significant investments in 2011 with our total capital
componenttext:
Thanks, Nick. Let me wrap up on Slide 18. We're off to their good start in 2011 as we outlined group in on plan and we are targeting the midpoint of guidance for the year. As you can see, we're making significant investments in 2011 with our total capital budget now above $1.7 billion. The spending coupled with the stream of investments going forward is the basis were expected to 5% to 6%  growth rate on maintaining a strong balance sheet and an attractive dividend.
As a reminder, Gerry Anderson's presentation at the AGA Financial Conference is on May 16 at 10:30 in the morning. And thank you, and we will now open up for questions, Lisa.

headline: DTE Energy Co., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: I could just speak at a high level that first of all, in our Power & Industrial business, we've outlined our growth projections to go out into 2015 where we're driving to get that business to net income level of $100 million. The 2 areas of growth, the Re
componenttext: I could just speak at a high level that first of all, in our Power & Industrial business, we've outlined our growth projections to go out into 2015 where we're driving to get that business to net income level of $100 million. The 2 areas of growth, the Renewable business line, which are the small coal plants that we're acquiring and converting to biomass the qualify for a renewable energy credits, so we have 5 projects that are either in construction or operating right now and we'll provide an update there. The other growth opportunities coming out of the reduced emission fields business line, this is again, where we licensed technology that when added to coal, it's used in the production of electricity reduces NOx by 20% in mercury by 40%. And we are in the process right now of citing those plants negotiating with charterparties around tax credits. And again, as this business line ramps up over the next several years will provide substantial earnings for us. It's a business line that qualifies for a tax credit that runs for 10 years. So he'll just provide an update on the insights on there. And then on midstream, we've had tremendous growth over the last five years and this year, were over $50 million of net income. We've outlined our aspirations to get that to by 2015 to $70 million of net income, and I think people have been  waiting this or something on the development side on this Bluestone project now. We've had a significant step forward in terms of reaching a tentative agreement with the counter party that would allow us to build out the lateral pipeline, and this could be a significant investment for the company and it's also a driver that will help drive net income growth industry over the next several years.

headline: DTE Energy Co., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: What we've outlined is going forward because of the capital that we're investing for our growth, we would see needs in the $100 million to $200 million range each year. We were able to drive that down this year and we're working hard on next year in the f
componenttext: What we've outlined is going forward because of the capital that we're investing for our growth, we would see needs in the $100 million to $200 million range each year. We were able to drive that down this year and we're working hard on next year in the forward years and. One of the offsets to that over the next several years will be monetizing our net properties. So as we think kind of refer to that, I think that this kind of a bank account that over time, as we monetize burn out that will reduce the need to issue equity. And we still believe when we issue equity going forward, it would it be a public issuance that would be doing this to our drip or small contributions to the pension plan.

headline: DTE Energy Co., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: I would get high level, first of all, that not only the one that we have that we're operating in MichCon, but also our relationship and interaction with the commission. And now the commissioners and staff is very, very constructive and so we have one of t
componenttext: I would get high level, first of all, that not only the one that we have that we're operating in MichCon, but also our relationship and interaction with the commission. And now the commissioners and staff is very, very constructive and so we have one of the better relationships that we've since I've work here for 15 years. So we work very collaboratively through these issues. We have some complexities. And as we go through these interim rate increases, one of the complexities is dealing with some of these trackers that are in place and it could be a the choice tracker. It could be the issue of trackers being reset or a trackers that go away and the clarity that you might need during that as you're going through interim rates. So when we file this case, we have filed the case and provided some options that we believe are viable options that could benefit customers during this time. And one of those options as an example was, not to reset the choice tracker but basically to continue it. So this ended up with one of the options, and the economics exactly what we have planned on. And in terms of the tone of what you see in the order right, I would just say that everyone has got different stakeholders that their writing, documents too, and I would not read too much into that. Our relationship is good. It doesn't mean we agree on everything, but I think the fact that we got through this self implementation and then the economics underlying and were able to spend by our guidance was a very positive signal.

componenttext: What we project going forward, so when we do our pioneer modeling right now, we do rate increases as one of the constraints that we're trying to manage to. So when we go out over 5 years, our rate increase, for example, the residential customers on average is under 5%. What's playing out this year was up pretty low. It's just over 2% and really the way to think about it is a choice reset to play out next year, but we've also not made any decision yet when will file our next case at Edison. we're trying to manage our costs in a way to stay out of rate cases as long as possible because that's the right thing for customers. So you get a choice tracker reset independent of a rate case and the reconciliation and then we can file subsequent rate case at a later date. Again, we've not made any decision on the rate cases in 2012. It's too early right now.

headline: DTE Energy Co., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, it doesn't necessarily bridge the gap, but I would say with the enabler to get to the 90%. The 90% , we are also working in Michigan because Michigan has 90% standard that we have to hit by 2015. So we we're on track on that anyway, but what we and
componenttext: Well, it doesn't necessarily bridge the gap, but I would say with the enabler to get to the 90%. The 90% , we are also working in Michigan because Michigan has 90% standard that we have to hit by 2015. So we we're on track on that anyway, but what we and others are learning is consistently getting 90% is difficult even with the technologies. So when this is supplemented with other technology, it's an enabler to consistently hit 90% or slightly above 90%, which is in the proposed new rule.

componenttextpreview: Well, part of what you're seeing their is that we we're shaping our acreage really around the NGLs and now what has been discovered is the oil play there. So we actually shut some acreage that we felt was less attractive and now we're I think roughly 85,0
componenttext: Well, part of what you're seeing their is that we we're shaping our acreage really around the NGLs and now what has been discovered is the oil play there. So we actually shut some acreage that we felt was less attractive and now we're I think roughly 85,000 acres. we're getting a $2 to $3 lift per Mcf because of NGLs and oil. And this is part of our strategy as we exit here to really optimize by proving up and what was now known as kind of the wet side of the gas play. So we're drilling specifically to prove up that pieces, and it'll provide us an exit ramp up that will provide what we're described in there was a significant improvement in dollars per Mcf produce.

headline: DTE Energy Co., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2011

componenttext: Yes, in I would describe it as a proved and unproved acreage in the mix. So there's some producing properties that there's more interest in, and there's also some transactions that we expect to happen in the region really around this whole oil play pieces. And it's something that we'll continue to monitor. In the meantime, we're investing modest amount of capital, but it's really being focused on this area of oil and NGLs.

componenttextpreview: Just on what's happening with the EPA that we believe the proposed rules are consistent with our expectation. But as you know, we and others have taken a position on so we think the timing is unrealistic and it's very aggressive. Tony early testified at A
componenttext: Just on what's happening with the EPA that we believe the proposed rules are consistent with our expectation. But as you know, we and others have taken a position on so we think the timing is unrealistic and it's very aggressive. Tony early testified at April 15 before the U.S. House Committee on energy and commerce and his testimony is  on our website. We encourage you to go and look at it, but we anticipate a lot of work is going right now, but I also thought that it's appropriate to remind folks that is the reserve margins are currently at 24% versus the required 12%. We also we're on a path already to pursue 90% mercury reduction in Michigan. So what we have outlined for you is that we are going to continue to build our scrubbers and SCR in Monroe and down the road, we anticipate putting additional environmental controls in some of the other larger newer units, but there will be smaller and older coal plants that will be closed. And some day, somewhere, we'll be adding new generation that will be likely to be gas generation. What you're hearing from the industry and from us also as we think the timetables are way too aggressive. And if not changed, we'll have it back not only in customer rates will be good impact local communities were jobs and property taxes and we'll continue to have to get a slow down a little bit.

headline: DTE Energy Co., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: Okay. Thank you, Lisa. Good morning, and welcome to our first quarter conference call. Before we get started, I encourage you to read the Safe Harbor statement on Page 2, including the reference to forward-looking statements.With me this morning are Pet
componenttext:
Okay. Thank you, Lisa. Good morning, and welcome to our first quarter conference call. Before we get started, I encourage you to read the Safe Harbor statement on Page 2, including the reference to forward-looking statements.
With me this morning are Peter Oleksiak; Nick Khouri and Mark Rolling. I also have members of the leadership team available for Q&A if necessary.
Let me start with an overview on Slide 5. We have plans that will provide 5% to 6%  earnings growth, and when coupled with our dividend of $2.24 per share, that provides a very attractive total shareholder return of 9% to 10%. This is offset with the key priority of maintaining a strong balance sheet. Our utility growth is driven by federal and state mandates, which even after aggressive cost management and capital efficiency work, will still generate 5% to 6% earnings growth.
The utility plans are supported by a constructive regulatory structure and our cost savings are a tool to allow us to earn our authorized returns. We continue to focus on operational excellence and customer satisfaction. And as an example of that, our complaints to the Michigan Public Service Commission are down by another 1/3 this year. And our focus on procurement in Michigan has about 40% of our annual $1.1 billion spend driven to Michigan as we focus on helping drive Michigan's economy forward. We also have meaningful growth opportunities in our Non-Utility businesses. 
The AGA Financial Conference is coming up here in May, and Gerry Anderson will be there with updates on the Power & Industrial business, including an update on the REF business line and on our Midstream business.
Now turning to Slide 6 is an overview for the quarter. We are a $1.11 per share in an operating earnings and we're right where we want to be in order to deliver our guidance of $3.40 to $3.70 per share. The 2 utilities are at 11%  return on equity last year and they remain on track to do the same this year. Yesterday, the Public Service Commission issued an order regarding Detroit Edison's self implementation, which was in line with our expectations and our plans. We had proposed several options to the commission in our original case filing which would get you to the same interim economics of $230 million. The commission shows the option of $107 million in interim rates by not resetting the base rates for choice and the continuation of the choice tracker. And when you put this together, it gets you back to the same outcome of $230 million in economics. This was the result of a collaborative effort with the staff, and we are pleased with the constructive outcome.
Both Power & Industrial and Gas Pipelines and Storage are also right on plan for the year. And just to note on the development side, we have entered into a letter of intent  with Southwestern Energy to construct a lateral pipe, which we have referred to in our IR materials as our Bluestone Project. Bluestone will be a wholly owned DTE pipeline connecting to both Millennium and to the Tennessee Pipeline and will transport gas from Southwestern's Marcellus Shale acreage. Terms of the -- of this arrangement are being negotiated right now as we work out the definitive agreement, and Gerry Anderson will provide an update on this project at AGA.
Peter will take you through the details in a moment on Energy Trading, but Energy Trading's tracking economically to our guidance target. This quarter's accounting earnings reflect timing within the year, and we continue to be comfortable with our total-year guidance for Energy Trading. So overall, we're off to a very good start for the year. Our balance sheet is also right where we want it to be and cash from operations was $700 million. We also have accelerated the timing of some of our Wind Projects with increases in our capital spending of about $300 million for the year. Although this is an increase to our 2011 CapEx guidance that we provided earlier in the year, it is within our renewable energy plan which has been approved by the commission. And Nick will take you through the details of the Wind Projects on the capital side. With that overview, now let me turn it over to Peter, who will take you through the quarter.

headline: DTE Energy Co., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Dave. Good morning to everyone. I'd like to start with Slide 8 and the first quarter earnings results. For the quarter, DTE's operating earnings was $1.11. I'd like to remind everyone that a reconciliation to GAAP reported earnings is contained in
componenttext:
Thanks, Dave. Good morning to everyone. I'd like to start with Slide 8 and the first quarter earnings results. For the quarter, DTE's operating earnings was $1.11. I'd like to remind everyone that a reconciliation to GAAP reported earnings is contained in the appendix. Detroit Edison contributed $0.57, and MichCon, which typically has a strong first quarter came in at $0.49. The Non-Utility segments combined earned $0.15. The drivers for the Non-Utility first quarter results were Gas Storage and Pipelines at $0.09, Power & Industrial projects at $0.06, Energy Trading at $0.01, Unconventional Gas Production at $0.01 loss. Finally, Corporate & Other had a loss of $0.10 in the quarter. 
Let's move to Slide 9 and a summary of the quarter-over-quarter performance by segment. Operating earnings for consolidated DTE Energy are down $41 million for the quarter. Together, our core utilities, Edison and MichCon had $10 million of earnings over the prior year, and I'll be providing additional details on the 2 utility companies later in the presentation.
Our Non-Utility segments are down $42 million, primarily driven by our Energy Trading segment down $36 million, which had historically high income in the first quarter last year. I'll provide more color on the Energy Trading performance in a moment. Power & Industrial projects was down $8 million, resulting from non-repeating earnings last year from the steel energy fuel's [ph] tax credit and favorable coal pricing.
Gas Storage and Pipelines and Unconventional Gas Production earnings are up slightly from the prior year. Corporate & Other was down $9 million from last year, due to a onetime 2010 tax benefit. Before I move from this page, just a few more words on the Energy Trading's first quarter performance. As you recall, we lowered the income range in our 2011 guidance for the Trading business to a midpoint of $25 million, down by a more historical average of $40 million to $50 million We are on track to achieve this midpoint of guidance for this segment in 2011.
The first quarter is off to a strong start for new transactions. On Page 21 of the appendix, we provided our standard page, which shows both economic and accounting performance. On that page, you will see we have $22 million of economic income, which is not recognized yet for accounting purposes. There are numerous transactions we entered into in the first quarter that will not start recognizing income until the physical delivery of the power or gas. An example of this is a coal-requirement [ph] gas transaction where the gas is delivered starting in the fourth quarter. We expect a good portion of the 22 million of tonnage to flow through operating earnings in the fourth quarter of this year.
As a result, the next 2 quarters of accounting income could be relatively flat for our Energy Trading business.
Now I'd like to go through some quarterly details of the utility companies beginning with Detroit Edison on Slide 10. Operating earnings for Detroit Edison was $97 million, up $6 million from the prior year. Margin for the quarter was up $8 million, driven primarily by energy efficiency incentives recorded in the first quarter of 2011 after receiving a favorable order in our efficiency reconciliation related to achieving prior year incentives. Even though we have revenue decoupling with our electric utility, we still closely monitor underlying electric load. Overall, temperature normal, electric load in the territory was up 1% in the quarter. We continue to see positive signs of economic improvement in Michigan, translating into an increased sales.
On the expense side, O&M was higher as a result of timing power plant maintenance and one-time benefit savings realized in 2010. In addition, in 2011, we have experience lower interest expense in favorable first quarter of 2011 property tax settlement at Detroit Edison.
Moving onto Page 11, a review of MichCon's performance. As mentioned earlier, the first quarter is typically the strongest in the seasonal Gas Utility business. Operating earnings for MichCon was $83 million, up $4 million from the prior year. The primary driver was $16 million of favorable weather impacts as the quarter saw 14% pickup in heating degree days compared to 2010. Margin that other than was down $9 million, primarily driven by the fact that a final rates in the June 2010 order, which carried into the first quarter of 2011 are lower than the south implementation executed in the first quarter of 2010.  In addition, maintenance expenses were up slightly this quarter, due to an increase in schedule in main service repairs. That concludes an update on our earnings for the quarter. I'd like to turn discussion over to Nick Khouri, who will cover cash flow and capital expenditures.

headline: DTE Energy Co., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Peter, and good morning, everyone. As always, improved cash flow and balance sheet strength remains a key priority for management and the board of directors. To the first three months of this year, DTE Energy's cash and balance sheet metrics are o
componenttext:
Thanks, Peter, and good morning, everyone. As always, improved cash flow and balance sheet strength remains a key priority for management and the board of directors. To the first three months of this year, DTE Energy's cash and balance sheet metrics are on track. In fact, nearly equal for the historically strong year we saw in 2010. 
Page 13 summarizes our balance sheet metrics. We expect to end this year within our targeted leverage in cash flow ranges.  In addition, we have made significant progress towards our 2011 funding requirements. We have completed our pension plan funding earlier this year than in past years, and we do not foresee the need for new equity in 2011. Liquidity remains strong with no expiring credit facilities until 2012.
Page 14 provides an overview of DTE's cash flow in the first quarter of this year versus the same period last year. Cash from operations, adjusted for the early pension contribution was about on par with the strong internal cash seen last year.  As expected, capital was up a bit compared to last year, which I will detail in just a minute. Total net cash reached approximately a positive $300 million in the first quarter of 2011. As in prior years, net cash is not equal across the four quarters of the year. Both working capital requirements and capital spending is back-loaded towards the end of the year.
Page 15 details first quarter capital spending. Year-to-date capital spending is about on par with last year for MichCon and the Non-Utility businesses. Capital is higher in Detroit Edison, reflecting an expected increase in environmental spending and the timing of plant outages.
Page 16 shows our revised guidance for 2011 cash and capital. The only change from the original guidance is higher renewable investments at Detroit Edison. As Dave mentioned, we were presented with an opportunity to accelerate the timing of our wind investment in Michigan. Renewable capital in 2011 is now projected at $350 million, up from the original guidance of $50 million. Expense renewable investments at Detroit Edison are funded with the preexisting surcharge, a new capital can be supported without an increase in customer rates while still maintaining our balance sheet targets.
In summary, DTE's cash and balance sheet targets are on track with year-to-date actuals nearing the historically strong year we saw in 2010, allowing us to accelerate our investment in the Renewable portfolio of Detroit Edison.
Now let me turn it back to Dave to wrap up.

headline: DTE Energy Co., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Nick. Let me wrap up on Slide 18. We're off to a very good start in 2011, as we outlined for you every group that's on plan and we are targeting the midpoint of guidance for the year. As you can see, we're making significant investments in 2011 wi
componenttext:
Thanks, Nick. Let me wrap up on Slide 18. We're off to a very good start in 2011, as we outlined for you every group that's on plan and we are targeting the midpoint of guidance for the year. As you can see, we're making significant investments in 2011 with our total capital budget now above $1.7 billion. The spending coupled with the stream of investments going forward is the basis for our expected 5% to 6% growth rate on maintaining a strong balance sheet and an attractive dividend.
As a reminder, Gerry Anderson's presentation at the AGA Financial Conference is on May 16 at 10:30 in the morning. And thank you, and we will now open up for questions, Lisa.

headline: DTE Energy Co., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: I could just speak at a high level that. First of all, in our Power & Industrial business, we've outlined our growth projections to go out into 2015 where we're driving to get that business to a net income level of $100 million. The 2 areas of growth, the
componenttext: I could just speak at a high level that. First of all, in our Power & Industrial business, we've outlined our growth projections to go out into 2015 where we're driving to get that business to a net income level of $100 million. The 2 areas of growth, the Renewable business line, which are the small coal plants that we're acquiring and converting to biomass that qualify for renewable energy credits. So we have 5 projects that are either in construction or operating right now, and we'll provide an update there. The other growth opportunities coming out of the Reduced Emission Fields business line this is, again, where we've licensed technology that when added to coal, it's used in the production of electricity. It reduces NOx by 40% -- excuse me, 20% and mercury by 40%. And we are in the process right now of citing those plants, negotiating with counter parties around tax credits. And again, as this business line ramps up over the next several years, it'll provide substantial earnings for us. It's a business line that qualifies for a tax credit that runs for 10 years. So he'll just provide an update on the insights up there. And then on midstream, we've had tremendous growth over the last 5 years and this year, were over $50 million of net income. We've outlined our aspirations to get that to 2000 -- by 2015 to $70 million of net income, and I think people have been  waiting this hear something on the development side, and this Bluestone project now. We've had a significant step forward in terms of reaching a tentative agreement with a counter party that would allow us to build out the lateral pipeline. And this could be a significant investment for the company and it's also the driver that'll help drive net income growth industry to over the next several years.

headline: DTE Energy Co., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2011

headline: DTE Energy Co., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: What we've outlined is that, going forward, because of the capital that we're investing for our growth, we would see needs in the $100 million to $200 million range each year. We were able to drive that down this year and we're working hard on next year a
componenttext: What we've outlined is that, going forward, because of the capital that we're investing for our growth, we would see needs in the $100 million to $200 million range each year. We were able to drive that down this year and we're working hard on next year and the forward years. And one of the offsets to that over the next several years will be monetizing the Barnett properties. So as we kind of refer to that, I think of that as kind of a bank account that over time, as we monetize Barnett, that will reduce the need to issue equity. And we still believe when we issue equity going forward, it wouldn't it be a public issuance that we would be doing this to our drip or small contributions to the pension plan.

headline: DTE Energy Co., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: No. I would get, at a high level, first of all, say that not only the law that we have that we're operating in Michigan, but also our relationship and interaction with the commission. And now the commissioners and staff is very, very constructive and so w
componenttext: No. I would get, at a high level, first of all, say that not only the law that we have that we're operating in Michigan, but also our relationship and interaction with the commission. And now the commissioners and staff is very, very constructive and so we have one of the better relationships than we've had since -- I've worked here for 15 years. So we work very collaboratively through these issues. We have some complexities. And as we go through these interim rate increases, one of the complexities is dealing with some of these trackers that are in place, and it could be the choice tracker. It could be the issue of trackers being reset or a trackers that go away and the clarity that you might need during that, as you're going through interim rates. So when we file this case, we have filed the case and provided some options that we believe are viable options that could benefit customers during this time. And one of those options, as an example, was not to reset the choice tracker but basically to continue it. So this ended up with one of the options, and the economics are exactly what we had planned on. And in terms of the tone of what you see in the order right, I would just say that everyone has got different stakeholders that they're writing, documents too, and I would not read too much into that. Our relationship is good. It doesn't mean we agree on everything, but I think the fact that we got through this self implementation and then the economics are aligned and we're able to stand by our guidance is a very positive signal.

headline: DTE Energy Co., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2011

componenttext: When we project, going forward, so we -- when we do our pioneer modeling right now, we do rate increases as one of the constraints that we're trying to manage to. So when we go out over 5 years, our rate increase, for example, the residential customers on average is under 5%. What's playing out this year is actually pretty low. It's just over 2%. And really the way to think about it is this choice reset could play out next year, but we've also not made any decision yet on when we'll file our next case at Edison. We're trying to manage our costs in a way to stay out of rate cases as long as possible because that's the right thing for customers. So you get a bad choice tracker reset independent of a rate case and the reconciliation and then we can file subsequent rate case at a later date. And again, we've not made any decision on rate cases in 2012. It's too early right now.

componenttext: All right. And I guess one last question. On the mercury technology and mercury removals technology in P&I, when you guys look at the new oxides rule, the DPA called that the draft rule [ph], what sort of performance or what grouping of equipment or other inputs would you need to use your equipment plus other things to get to the kind of this 91% removal rate? Is there a -- is this a technology that bridges the gap that use a couple other lower-cost options?

headline: DTE Energy Co., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, it doesn't necessarily bridge the gap, but I'd say it would be an enabler to get to the 90%. The 90%, we are also working in MichCon because MichCon has a 90% standard that we have to hit by 2015. So we're on track on that anyways, but what we're --
componenttext: Well, it doesn't necessarily bridge the gap, but I'd say it would be an enabler to get to the 90%. The 90%, we are also working in MichCon because MichCon has a 90% standard that we have to hit by 2015. So we're on track on that anyways, but what we're -- we and others are learning is consistently hitting 90% is difficult even with other technologies. So when this is supplemented with other technology, it's an enabler to consistently hit 90% or slightly above 90%, which is in the proposed new rule.

headline: DTE Energy Co., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: So really the way we should think about this technology is you're able to offer it to help people understand -- make sure that with traditional controls, they will always hit their numbers. So it kind of is as a standalone piece of equipment, it's not of
componenttext: So really the way we should think about this technology is you're able to offer it to help people understand -- make sure that with traditional controls, they will always hit their numbers. So it kind of is as a standalone piece of equipment, it's not of great value against the toxics rule, but it's a good supplement to make sure your performance is at a fair interpretation.

componenttextpreview: Part of what you're seeing there is that we were reshaping our acreage really around the NGLs, and now what is being discovered is the oil play there. So we actually shut some acreage that we felt were less attractive, and now we're, I think, roughly over
componenttext: Part of what you're seeing there is that we were reshaping our acreage really around the NGLs, and now what is being discovered is the oil play there. So we actually shut some acreage that we felt were less attractive, and now we're, I think, roughly over 85,000 acres. we're getting a $2 to $3 lift per Mcf because of NGLs and oil. And this is part of our strategy as we exit here to really optimize by proving up in what was now known as kind of the wet side of the gas play. So we're drilling specifically to prove up that pieces, and then it'll provide us an exit ramp that'll provide what we're describing here which is a significant improvement in dollars per Mcf produced.

And it's something that we continue to monitor. And in the meantime, we're investing modest amounts of capital, but it's really being focused on this area of oil and NGLs.

componenttext: Just on what's happening with the EPA that we believe the proposed rules are consistent with our expectation. But as you know, we and others have taken a position on and so we think the timing is unrealistic and it's very aggressive. Tony Earley [Anthony F. Earley] testified on April 15 before the U.S. House Committee on Energy and Commerce, and his testimony is on our website. We encourage you to go out and look at it, but we anticipated a lot of where this is going right now, but I also thought that it's appropriate to remind folks that we might sell reserved margins that are currently at 24% versus the required 12%. We also were on a path already to pursue 90% mercury reduction in MichCon. So what we have outlined for you is that we are going to continue to build our scrubbers and SCR at Monroe. And down the road, we anticipate putting additional environmental controls in some of the other larger, newer units, but there will be smaller and older coal plants that will be closed. And someday, somewhere, we'll be adding a new generation that would be likely to be gas generation. So I think what you're hearing from the industry and from us also is that we think the timetables are way too aggressive. And if not changed, we'll have impact not only on customer rates but could impact local communities with jobs and property taxes, and we'll continue to advocate to get to slow down a little bit.
